title: 107_s156
content:
The "After School Education and Anti-Crime Act of 2001" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students, reduce juvenile crime, and prevent youth from becoming victims of crime by providing productive activities during after school hours. Congress finds that today's youth face increased social risks, spend more time unsupervised, and are most at risk of violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. Academic failure consequences are dire, and after school programs help address social issues. Governors and law enforcement officials support increasing after school programs. Sheriffs, prosecutors, and police organizations representing 360,000 officers urge public officials to provide after school programs for children and teens in the US, emphasizing the importance of safe and positive learning environments during those hours. The Act aims to increase academic success, promote safe after-school environments, provide alternatives to negative activities, and reduce juvenile crime. It also amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to increase program authorization. Section 10904 of the Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to require recipients to provide a minimum of 35% of the annual project cost from sources other than federal funds, and not exceed 25% from funds provided by the Secretary under other federal programs. The recipient must ensure that 35% of the annual project cost comes from non-Federal sources and not exceed 25% from funds provided by the Secretary under other Federal programs. SEC. 7. USES OF FUNDS. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to allow grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers. The centers may offer activities including job skills preparation, mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, technology training, drug/alcohol/gang prevention, health/nutrition counseling, and after school programs with specified components. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act allows grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers. Activities may include job skills preparation, mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, technology training, drug/alcohol/gang prevention, health/nutrition counseling, and after school programs with expanded opportunities for children or youth. At least 2/3 of the appropriated amount must be used for after school programs. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION.

Amendment to Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act includes provisions for local educational agencies, schools, or consortia to involve volunteers from various communities, engage youth in designing after school activities, conduct outreach creatively, request donations of equipment, and collaborate with park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities.

SEC. 9. COMMUNITY LEARNING CENTER DEFINED. SEC. 9. COMMUNITY LEARNING CENTER DEFINED. Section 10906 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include law enforcement organizations such as the Police Athletic and Activity League. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 10907 is amended to increase funding for fiscal years 2002-2006 to carry out this part. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect on October 1, 2001.
